-----but lower average fares. Notwithstanding Deputy Boland's point about her area, the fare initiatives are encouraging people to become regular users of public transport.

There was a deliberate decision though to prioritise new routes over enhancing or sustaining existing services. That is obvious. I turn to the NDP sectoral plan announced last week and to DART+ West. We are through planning, there are no legal issues and it is included in the sectoral plan to start construction in 2027. There is an indicative figure of €1 billion. Is that just for the start of the construction? Will more funding have to be allocated at a later stage? Will the project be broken down into different phases? Does it have to go through any further public spending gates or is that it?

In the context of any project there will be that transparency piece and the different gates that have to be navigated to ensure the project is transparent. The Department will engage with the relevant stakeholders. In the context of the timeline today, with the publication of the accelerated infrastructure plan it is about ensuring we deliver projects quicker, on time and on budget. The actual project costs will vary. In the context of the €1 billion, it is the standard Department of public expenditure cost band. That is what it is allocated under. It is not the actual specific project cost. The short answer to the Deputy is that yes, it will require further approvals, because if it did not the Deputy would come in here on a different day with a different set of questions. That is part of what we do. The question perhaps is if we should take the accelerated infrastructure plan and use that for some of the projects the Deputy spoke about there.

We have to look at the hurdles involved in progressing essential State infrastructure. The NDP sectoral plan allocates €1 billion plus to DART+ West. I do not want to be sitting here in a year's time in front of the NTA saying it has to wait for another allocation to start the next phase, especially with MetroLink and the problems that have to be overcome legally with that. We need to push on and reduce the number of gates and stages to try to construct this piece of infrastructure as soon as possible.
I agree with the Deputy. We need to do things better and faster. DART+ West will need to go to tender and then for further approval to have the contract signed.
I understand that piece.

What we all share is the need to accelerate delivery on behalf of people. I was in Qatar recently and they were building infrastructure projects much faster than here. That poses the question of why and what we can do differently. That fundamental question needs to be addressed by us, as a State. That will have an implication for people at local level perhaps but what serves the greater good?
Let us push on.

What influence does the Minister of State have in talking to Irish Rail as regards trains going through Portlaoise on to Ballybrophy that can take students to Thurles and places like that? Is there any joined-up thinking because I have loads of students who would love to go on the train? Their parents would love to have them on the train. As the Minister of State knows, even secondary schools are having a problem now because there are students driving to school.

In my day, going to school, no one had a car. I remember one young lad coming in a tractor, but that was all. It was not me. Could there be more joined-up thinking from that point of view to get the best possible results from our time on the tracks?

The railway track is the most truesome infrastructure that we have in this country. It is not that long since somebody, somewhere, decided to take up tracks. I would love to know what the thinking behind closing down railways was. I will leave that aside, because it is not a history lesson here. I would love to see more openings for carriages on trains and more stopping of trains at particular times. Even in the school terms, if there was a change, that would allow students to be brought from A to B. That would be great.

In the national development plan, in this famous envelope, the Portlaoise northern orbital route is not contained in the first round that was opened the other day. Who actually says what is to be done? Who actually says we are going to put a road here and not put a road there? If you take the town I represent now, it has north of 30,000 people in it. You see other places that have half of that population getting something. I want to know who that group of people are. I would love to sit down with them and ask them to tell me why we did not tick boxes. I would love to know that, because as the Minister of State knows, all our traffic is coming through Portlaoise and all going to the west of Ireland. It has nowhere else to go. It cannot hide. We are going down by schools and everything like that. I cannot understand, in my head, why the Portlaoise northern orbital route is not up at the top. I would like the people sitting there to tell me why they are not doing it.

I will ask the Minister of State, Deputy Canney, who has responsibility for rail, to engage with the Deputy, but also to speak to the new chief executive of Irish Rail about the matter the Deputy raised. On the NDP envelope regarding the roads, the short answer is that the local authority, as the Deputy knows as a long-time public representative, is the statutory roads authority. It makes requests. It prioritises-----
That is the way it used to be anyway.
I know but that is the answer.
That was all part of it 40 years ago.
I know well.
We have been looking for this for 25 years. All our stuff is up here, but somebody made a decision. Who made the decision not to put roads in? Who makes that decision?

The answer is that a collective of a number of different entities make the decision but I go back to my fundamental point that the local authority, as the statutory roads authority, is the driver of projects locally.
I am talking about the money. Do not come and say that to me, please.
We are well over time.
Who gives the money? I asked a simple question, to be fair. All I asked was who recommends the investment for roads in different areas.
My answer remains the same. As the Deputy knows quite well, local authorities prioritise projects and they recommend to the Department and TII-----
Who makes the decision then?
It is a collective decision then.
I thank the Minister of State and his officials for attending and engaging with the committee.
